choices.B: interface gigabitethernet0/0/1 ethernet dot1ad uni c-port
choices.C: interface gigabitethernet0/0/1 ethernet dot1ad uni nni
choices.A: interface gigabitethernet0/0/1 ethernet dot1ad uni s-port

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring IEEE 802. 1ad on the access port on a new Cisco router. The access port handles traffic from multiple customer VLANs, and it is expected to mark allcustomer traffic to the same VLAN without dropping any traffic. Which configuration must the engineer apply?

discussion.content: Anybody have a good explanation about this?

comments.content:
Yes, here is the link:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/asr920/configuration/guide/ce/b_ce_xe-313s-asr920-book/b_ce_xe-313s-asr920-book_chapter_01100.html#concept_53CC8A5B450F4F83A3F3AC572FF72A86

S-UNI—an access port that provides the same service to all customer VLANs entering the interface, marking all C-VLANs entering the port with the same S-VLAN. In this mode, the customer's port is configured as a trunk port, and traffic entering the S-UNI is tagged. Use the ethernet dot1ad uni s-port interface configuration command on an access port with an access VLAN.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the characteristics from the left onto the corresponding radio splitting approaches on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Rough explanations:
Low level split
4G/5G Tower----Baseband Unit(BBU)-----Core network
Fronthaul: network between tower and BBU
Backhaul: network between BBU and core
requires more bandwidth


High level Split
4G/5G Tower----[BBU far edge-------BBU edge]------Core network
Midhaul: network between different units within BBU
its used for low-latency communication so requires low RTT

Low level split (centralized) : high bandwidth, fronthaul
High level split (distributed): lower delay , midhaul

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A large service provider is migrating device management from Layer 2 VLAN-based to Layer 3 IP-based solution. An engineer must configure the ISIS solution with these requirements:
✑ Network management server IP 172.16.10.1 must be advertised from the core MPLS network to the regional domain.
✑ The external network 202.10.0.0/24 must not establish ISIS peering with the R5 router.
✑ The regional network must prevent sending unnecessary hello packets and flooding the routing tables of the R5 router.
Which two ISIS parameters must be implemented to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
B and E

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/iproute_isis/command/reference/irs_book/irs_is1.html

Selected Answer: BE
It should be B/E

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic of data modeling language?

choices.B: It separates configuration and state data.
choices.A: It provides an interface for state data.
choices.C: It ensures devices are individually configured.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Technically it's both wavelength and frequency of the optical signal (higher frequency = shorter wavelength). But wavelength is certainly what Cisco would want you to answer here.

questions.question_text: What does DWDM use to combine multiple optical signals?
